title: middleware
description: Nuxt provides middleware to run code before navigating to a particular route.

children.value: framework you can use throughout your application, ideal for extracting code that you want to run before navigating to a particular route.
There are three kinds of route middleware:
Anonymous (or inline) route middleware are defined directly within the page.
Named route middleware, placed in the
and automatically loaded via asynchronous import when used on a page.
Global route middleware, placed in the
suffix and is run on every route change.
The first two kinds of route middleware can be defined in
Name of middleware are normalized to kebab-case:
Route middleware run within the Vue part of your Nuxt app. Despite the similar name, they are completely different from
, which are run in the Nitro server part of your app.
Route middleware are navigation guards that receive the current route and the next route as arguments.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: Object of decoded params extracted from the
This will abort navigation within a Nuxt route middleware handler.
// In a real app you would probably not redirect every route to `/`
// however it is important to check `to.path` before redirecting or you
// might get an infinite redirect loop
Percentage encoded pathname section of the URL.
Nuxt provides two globally available helpers that can be returned directly from the middleware.
- Aborts the navigation, with an optional error message.
redirect or route cancellation is handled by returning a value from the middleware
or no return at all) - does not block navigation and will move to the next middleware function, if any, or complete the route navigation
- redirects to the given path and will set the redirect code to
if the redirect happens on the server side
- redirects to the given path and will set the redirect code to
if the redirect happens on the server side
- rejects the current navigation with an error
We recommend using the helper functions above for performing redirects or stopping navigation. Other possible return values described in
may work but there may be breaking changes in future.
Middleware runs in the following order:
Page defined middleware order (if there are multiple middleware declared with the array syntax)
For example, assuming you have the following middleware and component:

props.className: language-text shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({
  middleware: [
    function (to, from) {
      // Custom inline middleware
    },
    'auth',
  ],
});
</script>

children.value: You can expect the middleware to be run in the following order:
By default, global middleware is executed alphabetically based on the filename.
However, there may be times you want to define a specific order. For example, in the last scenario,
. In that case, we recommend prefixing global middleware with 'alphabetical' numbering.

props.className: language-text shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: In case you're new to 'alphabetical' numbering, remember that filenames are sorted as strings, not as numeric values. For example,
. This is why the example prefixes single digit numbers with

If your site is server-rendered or generated, middleware for the initial page will be executed both when the page is rendered and then again on the client. This might be needed if your middleware needs a browser environment, such as if you have a generated site, aggressively cache responses, or want to read a value from local storage.
However, if you want to avoid this behaviour you can do so:

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp

children.value: // skip middleware on client side entirely
// or only skip middleware on initial client load
Throws an error if Nuxt instance is unavailable.
Rendering an error page is an entirely separate page load, meaning any registered middleware will run again. You can use
in middleware to check if an error is being handled.
It is possible to add global or named route middleware manually using the
helper function, such as from within a plugin.

children.value: In your page file, you can reference this route middleware:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({
  middleware: ["auth"]
  // or middleware: 'auth'
})
</script>
